Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Novel Quantum Hall and Correlation Physics in Topological Band Structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This CAREER award supports theoretical research and education to investigate the new quantum Hall and correlation physics in materials involving topological band structures. Using quantum field theory, variational Monte Carlo, exact diagonalization and other modern quantum many-body techniques, the PI will pursue four main research directions:

(1) Exploring novel phases of matter in transition metal oxide heterostructures, where various topological phases may emerge. These include possible high-temperature quantum spin hall phases and correlation induced fractional quantum hall phases in the absence of an external magnetic field.

(2) Understanding the nature of the abelian and non-abelian fractional Chern insulators and topological insulators. The research will focus on constructing wavefunctions for these states and understanding their low energy properties.

(3) Investigating correlated quantum Hall effects of the 2D Dirac surface states of a 3D topological insulator.

(4) Understanding the quantum Hall effects and experimental signatures of 3D Weyl semi-metal phases, which may be realized in materials such as pyrochlore iridates.

The educational activities associated with this award include developing pedagogical courses and a seminar series for undergraduate and graduate students, with emphasis on the new phases of matter discovered in modern condensed matter physics. These are intended to excite students to study and actively pursue research in physics. Outreach activities include a lecture series aimed at sparking the interest in science and technology among middle school students, especially in low-income areas. These lectures are designed to expose the young audience to some striking advances in the history of modern science and technology, and their roles in our everyday life. To generate interest in science over a broader scale, the PI will develop an interactive website for hosting an overview of his research activities as well as teaching materials.

NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
This CAREER award supports theoretical research and education to investigate a recently discovered new state of electronic matter that arises in certain materials called topological insulators. Materials are often classified according to the ways electrons organize themselves within the material, leading to materials types that include: metals if they conduct electricity, insulators if they do not, and the familiar magnet. Fundamental concepts make this classification even more precise. Topological insulators lie outside this traditional classification scheme making them very important from a fundamental science perspective. They are at once an insulator in the bulk of the material, but unlike an ordinary insulator that forms the basis of modern electronics, there is a metal-like state on the surfaces and edges of the insulator. The metal-like state is an intrinsic property of the material that is a consequence of the way electrons in the bulk organize themselves. This state hosts striking phenomena such as ideal electric transport on the boundaries of the material without losing any energy. This project focuses on answering fundamental scientific questions about topological insulators: What are the fundamental properties of these topological phases? How can they be found in practical materials? What are their potential applications? The PI will also investigate many promising candidate materials for topological phases, and the effect of an external magnetic field on these phases. The conducting surfaces of topological insulators and the possibility of new phenomena that occur when a topological insulator is brought into contact with other materials, suggests many possible technological applications from new device technologies to high performance computer technologies based on the manipulation of quantum mechanical states.

These are intended to excite students to study and actively pursue research in physics. POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported theoretical research and educational activities in understanding topological quantum states of matter.  States of matter form a central subject of condensed matter physics. Traditional states of matter include liquid, solid, magnet, etc.; and they form when an enormous number of particles (e.g. atoms or molecules) organize themselves together.

Recent developments in physics demonstrate the existence of new topological states of matter that are intrinsically quantum mechanical with no classical analog. Usually physical properties of a state of matter are characterized by continuous variables. However topological states of matter host robust "integer-like" physical properties such as quantized dissipationless electric transport. Importantly, these states of matter are found in practical materials under rather normal conditions, which suggests a vast potential of future applications. Conceptually these topological states of matter are intimately related to quantum information science, and topology in modern mathematics.

Although a few topological states have been discovered in experiments, it is theoretically known that many more of them are yet to be discovered. The core scientific issues addressed in this project include: (1) How to systematically understand topological states? (2) What are the unique novel physical properties in topological states? (3) Where to find them in materials?

Along these directions, the PI has made several significant contributions in this project. The PI’s group partially classified so-called symmetry-enriched topological states, in which symmetry and long-range quantum entanglement both play important roles. This is among the first works revealing the possibility of systematical understanding symmetry-enriched topological states. In another piece of work, the PI’s group generalized the braiding statistics of particles in two spatial dimensions into the braiding statistics involving three loop objects in three spatial dimensions. This three-loop braiding can serve as a novel diagnosis for three-dimensional topological states, and has been applied in many other works.

The PI’s group pointed out a general relation between seeming unrelated two types of topological states: symmetry-enriched topological states and so-called symmetry-protected topological states. They are different since the latter ones do not feature long-range quantum entanglement. The relation pointed out by the PI’s group is a symmetric version of gauge confinement mechanism. Gauge confinement is a fundamental problem in physics. This work not only provides new insights relating symmetric gauge theories and topological states, but also gives new guiding principles of realizing symmetry-protected topological states.

Weyl semimetals are topological states and were recently discovered in materials like TaAs. The low energy electrons in these materials move in an emergent relativistic fashion and feature “handednesses”, or chiralities. With collaborators, the PI’s group predicted a new property of Weyl semimetals: the photoinduced anomalous Hall effect, which is an interesting interplay between chiral electrons and chiral photons --- the circularly polarized light. The PI’s group also predicted another novel property of Weyl semimetals: the divergent nonlinear optical responses. For instance, when a Weyl semimetal is illuminated by a low frequency light, the relativistic motion of electrons is predicted to give an anomalously large steady-state electric current.

Many exotic topological states need strong interactions to stabilize. In order to investigate such strongly interacting quantum systems, intensive numerical simulations are usually required. Previously available numerical simulation methods meet various challenges and it is highly desirable to develop and apply new numerical simulation methods. The PI’s group developed a numerical simulation scheme and algorithms based on symmetric tensor-networks – a new theoretical language for many-particle quantum mechanics. The PI’s group also applied a combination of numerical methods to search for topological states in realistic models. For example, the PI’s group identified topological states in various regimes for the ¼-doped interacting quantum models on the honeycomb lattice.

This project supported and provided research opportunities for two postdoc scholars and four graduate students. One of the former postdoc scholar joined an institution in France as a member. And one of the former graduate student moved to California for a prestigious postdoc fellowship position. In addition, this project provided research opportunities for one undergraduate student.

The educational activates in this project also include developing new course materials by integrating the modern developments of quantum condensed matter physics into graduate and undergraduate curriculum. For instance, the topic of topological states of matter was incorporated into the Solid State Physics course taught by the PI. Moreover, the PI gave a lecture series in the Theory Winter School at National High Magnetic Field Lab in 2014. At the PI’s institution, The PI gave lecture series to domestic undergraduate students in the REU program, and in the Physics Research Symposium series for the Society of Physics Students.

As an outreach activity, the PI developed and maintained a website hosting the teaching materials and non-technical introductions to research activities of the PI’s group. These efforts are aimed at sparking interest in science of technology among the general public.
